text: hey everyone Anthony Pham tanto here
Internet's busiest music nerd and it is
time for a review of the new self-titled
murmur album this is the sophomore LP
from the chicago-based metal outfit
murmur this new LP of theirs is being
dropped right at the start of this year
by a label which is a subdivision of
Season Of Mist records a pretty heavy
hitter in the metal underground as far
as labels go if you weren't aware this
band's 2010 debut LP slipped by me
however when looking through their back
catalogue after listening to this new
album of theirs I was not surprised to
find that they actually have a split out
with another experimental metal outfit
from the Midwest knock Miss diem and I'm
not surprised because I feel like these
two bands share a lot of common ground I
do think they have a similar stylistic
approach in that black metal is a really
huge foundational influence for the
music that both of these groups create
in the case of murmur seems to inform
their retched vocals their
claustrophobic recording and they're
sort of dismal chord progressions but
both bands only really use black metal
as a bit of a home base as they reach
out and experiment with other genres
incorporating them into this
traditionally dark sound even though the
first track on this LP is a pretty harsh
wake-up call with some obvious black
metal influences as this song and this
entire album progresses elements of
experimental rock jazz rock jazz fusion
all reveal themselves the band might jam
on like an off-kilter riff or an odd
time signature or create some chaos with
some really glitchy electronics or a
flurry of percussion from drummer
Charlie Werber whose playing is actually
a huge highlight on nearly every track
here the track recuerdo s-- is kind of a
an acoustic guitar driven funky
interlude that's pretty nice come down
and there are moments on this LP as well
where the band seems to embrace that
noisy my numbing riff repetition of a
van like swans which happens on the
track king in yellow a song that isn't
my favorite on here mostly because I do
think that repetition makes the song
overstay its welcome a little bit the
vocals on this thing can be really
aggressive and abrasive and in other
spots here kind of melodic on the song
when blood leaves
have these sort of eerie deadpan vocal
harmonies that have such a cultish vibe
to them I love it on the opening track
here there are some really heavenly
chorus vocals hanging in the background
and whether they're sampled or
synthesized or not they add a really
nice and sort of pretty sound to this
very evil metal recording and to speak
to the more freakish side of this record
there is the song Zeta 2 part 2 where
over these really oddly shaped riffs
that are locked in really tightly with
the drums we're getting what is sort of
heavy metal scatting even the final song
in this LP is a cover of King Crimson's
larks tongues and aspect part to really
more of a bonus track for those who are
interested but that sort of shows you
where this band is coming from they
really love their progressive rock they
really love their jazz rock and not that
they should be ashamed either of what
bands they're sort of taking ideas for
them to make this record because this is
they're blending all these influences so
seamlessly that this self-titled record
is a little refreshing in a sense for
the most part the band understands
tension and release and how it can use
these two things to drag songs on for
long periods of time and keep it
interesting this talent is best
displayed on the first three tracks here
for one the song water for water which
has this really dismal opening with
acoustic guitars and it builds really
slowly with some guitar leads that are
wailing and electric piano keys that are
scattered about the percussion is all
over the place and suddenly the song
just explodes into a wall of blast beats
these very messy and chaotic tremolo
Pickett ARS and like I said earlier
these heavenly background vocals that
sort of as they return raise the
climaxes of the song higher and higher
then there's the song bull of Crete
which has all these really sharp
shrill guitar chords and riffs playing
over this drumming that the more I
listened to it it just reminds me of
animal from the Muppets I can't really
explain it in any other way while I do
know the stylistic influences that make
Charlie Weber play the way that he does
I just imagine him playing this track
and just see his hands all over the
place the song eventually just glides
into this ascending chord progression
that I absolutely love
the track then moves through a series of
riffs and dismal interludes before it
comes back and returns to a lot of the
same themes but with a lot more drama
and power those are two words I would
use to describe the next track on here
as well almalik the longest song here
with more than 11 minutes in length and
a track that sticks out to me because of
the greatest difference between one part
and another part in another part in the
song I mean there are so many
hard-hitting riffs right at the
beginning of this track but then it just
boils down very quickly into this deep
dark depressing bleak set of guitar
passages and they're really murky bass
riffs and the sort of sparse electric
piano it reminds me of darker groups in
progressive rock music like magma or
Guapo the band essentially structures
this album in a way where they hit you
with these three monsters and then sort
of go down a little bit into this funky
interlude which is a very great track
and then hit you with three more tracks
that seem to be sort of linked into one
another to me there are only two major
weak points on this LP and they don't
even really distract me that much from
enjoying the album for one the vocals
sometimes they're chilling and really
aggressive sometimes they're melodic
other times they're kind of
straightforward and shouting and pretty
intelligible the vocals definitely get
the job done they don't bore me but they
don't wow me on here as much as some of
the guitar playing and especially the
drumming however this might also be due
to how buried the vocals feel in the
overall recording which is sort of my
second issue with this album what
exactly murmur is doing on this record
the detail of it feels slightly obscured
by the kind of grimy sound that this
record has to offer and while I'm sure
on some level it's an aesthetic choice
it did take me a few listens to kind of
make heads or tails of the nuances to
the playing on this thing so I thought
this thing was really great I'd highly
recommend it I mean there was a really
visceral jagged progressive rock riffs
on this thing fantastic diverse drumming
with a lot of fluidity excitement these
guys keep this sound gritty and they
keep the playing strong and I think the
album itself is pretty cohesive from
front to back
with a lot of songs on here
complimenting one another segue into to
another or explore different sounds or
experiments to keep this record from
getting too redundant I wish the sound
on this thing was a little more
hard-hitting and I wish the ending was a
bit more climactic it's definitely one
of the most dismal tracks on this entire
record but still I am feeling the
lightest and fluffiest of eights on this
thing transition if you've given this
record to listen what did you think of
it did you love it hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantan Oh murmur
forever
